pli-tv-pvr17:1.1: At that time the Buddha, the Lord was staying near Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove in Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
pli-tv-pvr17:1.2: Then the venerable Upāli approached the Lord; having approached and greeted the Lord he sat down at a respectful distance.
pli-tv-pvr17:1.3: As he was sitting down at a respectful distance, the venerable Upāli spoke thus to the Lord,
pli-tv-pvr17:1.4: “Possessed of how many qualities, revered sir, should a monk not live independently for as long as life lasts?”
pli-tv-pvr17:2.1: “If a monk is possessed of five qualities, Upāli, he should not live independently for as long as life lasts.
pli-tv-pvr17:2.3: If he does not know the Observance, if he does not know the formal act for the Observance, if he does not know the Pātimokkha, if he does not know the recital of the Pātimokkha, if it is less than five years (since his ordination).
pli-tv-pvr17:2.4: Possessed of these five qualities, Upāli, a monk should not live independently for as long as life lasts.
pli-tv-pvr17:2.5: Possessed of five qualities, Upāli, a monk may live independently for as long as life lasts.
pli-tv-pvr17:2.7: If he knows the Observance … the formal act for the Observance … if it is five years or more than five years (since his ordination).
pli-tv-pvr17:3.1: And if a monk is possessed of five further qualities, Upāli, he should not live independently for as long as life lasts.
pli-tv-pvr17:3.3: If he does not know the Invitation, if he does not know the formal act for the Invitation, if he does not know the Pātimokkha, if he does not know the recital of the Pātimokkha, if it is less than five years (since his ordination).
pli-tv-pvr17:3.5: Possessed of five qualities, Upāli a monk may live independently for as long as life lasts.

pli-tv-pvr17:4.3: If he does not know what is an offence and what is not an offence, if he does not know what is a slight and what a serious offence, if he does not know an offence that can be done away with and one that cannot be done away with, if he does not know what is a very bad offence and what is not a very bad one, if it is less than five years (since his ordination).

pli-tv-pvr17:4.8: Possessed of these five qualities, Upāli, a monk may live independently for as long as life lasts.”
pli-tv-pvr17:5.1: “If a monk is possessed of how many qualities, revered sir, should he not ordain, not give guidance, and a novice not attend him?”
pli-tv-pvr17:6.1: “If a monk is possessed of five qualities, Upāli, he should not ordain, he should not give guidance, a novice should not attend him.
pli-tv-pvr17:6.3: If he is not competent to tend or get (another) to tend a pupil or one who shares a cell and is ill, to allay or get (another) to allay dissatisfaction that has arisen, to dispel or get (another) to dispel, by means of _Dhamma_, remorse that has arisen, to lead him in what pertains to _Dhamma_, to lead him in what pertains to Discipline.
pli-tv-pvr17:6.4: Possessed of these five qualities, Upāli, a monk should not ordain, he should not give guidance, a novice should not attend him.
pli-tv-pvr17:6.5: Possessed of five qualities, Upāli, a monk may ordain, he may give guidance, a novice may attend him.
pli-tv-pvr17:6.7: If he is competent to tend … to lead him in what pertains to Discipline.
pli-tv-pvr17:6.8: Possessed of these five qualities … a novice may attend him.
pli-tv-pvr17:7.1: And if a monk is possessed of five further qualities … a novice should not attend him.
pli-tv-pvr17:7.3: If he is not competent to train a pupil or one who shares a cell in the training regarding the fundamentals of conduct, to lead him in the training regarding the fundamentals of the Brahma-faring, to lead him in the higher morality, to lead him in the higher thought, to lead him in the higher wisdom.
pli-tv-pvr17:7.4: Possessed of these five qualities … a novice should not attend him.
pli-tv-pvr17:7.5: Possessed of five qualities, Upāli, a monk may ordain, he may give guidance, a novice may attend him.
pli-tv-pvr17:7.7: If he is competent … to lead him in the higher wisdom.
pli-tv-pvr17:7.8: Possessed of these five qualities, Upāli, a monk may ordain, he may give guidance, a novice may attend him.”
pli-tv-pvr17:8.1: “If a monk is possessed of how many qualities, revered sir, should a formal act (against him) be carried out?”

pli-tv-pvr17:9.4: If a monk is possessed of these five qualities, Upāli, a formal act should be carried out against him.

pli-tv-pvr17:10.3: If, as regards morality, he has fallen away from moral habit, if, as regards behaviour, he has fallen away from good behaviour, if, as regards view, he has fallen away from right view, and if he is of wrong view, and has fallen away from a right mode of livelihood.
pli-tv-pvr17:11.1: And if a monk is possessed of five further qualities …

pli-tv-pvr17:14.3: If he is possessed of wrong bodily mode of livelihood … wrong verbal mode of livelihood … wrong bodily and verbal mode of livelihood, and if he is of wrong view, and has fallen away from a right mode of livelihood.

pli-tv-pvr17:16.3: If he falls into that same offence for which a formal act was carried out (against him) by an Order, or into another that is similar, or into one that is worse, if he finds fault with the formal act, if he finds fault with one who carried it out.

pli-tv-pvr17:27.1: “When a monk who is engaged in conflict, revered sir, is approaching an Order, having set up how many states within himself should he approach the Order?”
pli-tv-pvr17:28.1: “When a monk who is engaged in conflict, Upāli, is approaching an Order, having set up five states within himself should he approach the Order.
pli-tv-pvr17:28.3: When a monk who is engaged in conflict, Upāli, is approaching an Order he should approach the Order with a humble mind, with a mind (as though) it were removing dust; he should be skilled about seats and skilled about sitting down; he should sit down on a suitable seat without encroaching on (the space intended for) monks who are Elders and without keeping newly ordained monks from a seat; he should not talk in a desultory fashion nor about inferior (worldly) matters; he should speak _Dhamma_ himself or should ask another to do so, nor should he disdain the ariyan silence.
pli-tv-pvr17:28.4: If, Upāli, an Order is carrying out (formal) acts that should be carried out by a complete Order, but if this does not seem right to the monk, then, giving an explanation of (his) views, the “being all together” may be attained.
pli-tv-pvr17:28.5: What is the reason for this?
pli-tv-pvr17:28.6: He says, ‘Let me not be different from the Order.’
pli-tv-pvr17:28.7: When a monk who is engaged in conflict Upāli, is approaching an Order, having set up these five states within himself he should approach the Order.”

pli-tv-pvr17:33.1: “How many advantages are there, revered sir, for one who has mastery in Discipline?”
pli-tv-pvr17:34.1: “There are these five advantages, Upāli, for one who has mastery in Discipline.
pli-tv-pvr17:34.3: His own body of moral habit is well guarded, well protected, he is a shelter for those who are affected by scruples, confidently he lives in the midst of an Order, with _Dhamma_ he restrains adversaries from one who is well restrained, he is one practising for the stability of True _Dhamma_.
pli-tv-pvr17:34.4: These, Upāli, are the five advantages for who has mastery in Discipline.”

pli-tv-pvr17:54.1: “How many explanations of views, revered sir, are not legally valid?”
pli-tv-pvr17:55.1: “These five explanations of views, Upāli, are not legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr17:55.3: He explains a view by means of what is not an offence, he explains a view by means of an offence not leading on to confession, he explains a view by means of an offence that has been confessed, he explains a view by means of four, of five (people), he explains a view by means of a mental action of the mind.
pli-tv-pvr17:55.4: These five explanations of views, Upāli, are not legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr17:56.1: These five explanations of views, Upāli, are legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr17:56.3: He explains a view by means of what is an offence … by means of an offence leading on to confession … by means of an offence that has not been confessed … not by means of four or five (people), he explains a view not by means of a mental action of the mind.
pli-tv-pvr17:57.1: And five further explanations of views, Upāli, are not legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr17:57.3: He explains a view in the presence of one belonging to a different communion … in the presence of one standing on a different boundary … in the presence of one who is not a regular monk … by means of four or five (people), he explains a view by means of a mental activity of the mind.
pli-tv-pvr17:58.1: These five explanations of views, Upāli, are legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr17:58.3: He explains a view in the presence of one belonging to the same communion … in the presence of one standing on the same boundary … in the presence of one who is a regular monk … not by means of four or five, he explains a view not by means of a mental activity of the mind.
pli-tv-pvr17:58.4: These five explanations of views, Upāli, are legally valid.”
pli-tv-pvr17:59.1: “How many ways of accepting, revered sir, are not legally valid?”
pli-tv-pvr17:60.1: “These five ways of accepting, Upāli, are not legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr17:60.3: When something that is being given by means of body is not accepted by means of body, when something that is being given by means of body is not accepted by means of something attached to the body, when something that is being given by means of something attached to the body is not accepted by means of body, when something that is being given by means of something attached to the body is not accepted by means of something attached to the body, when something that is being given by means of what may be cast is not accepted by means of body or of something attached to the body.
pli-tv-pvr17:60.4: These are the five ways of accepting, Upāli, that are not legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr17:61.1: These five ways of accepting, Upāli, are legally valid.
pli-tv-pvr17:61.3: When something that is being given by means of body is accepted by means of body … when something that is being given by means of what may be cast is accepted by means of body or of something attached to the body.
pli-tv-pvr17:61.4: These five ways of accepting, Upāli, are legally valid.”

pli-tv-pvr17:240.1: “How many advantages are there, revered sir, in formally making _kaṭhina_ cloth?”
pli-tv-pvr17:241.1: “There are these five advantages, Upāli, in formally making _kaṭhina_ cloth.
pli-tv-pvr17:241.3: Going (to families for alms) without having asked for permission, walking (for alms) not taking the three robes, a group-meal, as much robe-material as is required, and whatever robe-material accrues there, that will be for them.
pli-tv-pvr17:241.4: These, Upāli, are the five advantages in formally making the _kaṭhina_ cloth.”
pli-tv-pvr17:242.1: “How many perils are there, revered sir, for one of muddled mindfulness, not clearly conscious, when he has fallen asleep?”
pli-tv-pvr17:243.1: “There are these five perils, Upāli, for one of muddled mindfulness … when he has fallen asleep.
pli-tv-pvr17:243.3: He sleeps uneasily, he wakes uneasily, he sees an evil dream, devatās do not guard him, impurity is emitted.
pli-tv-pvr17:243.4: These are the five perils … when he has fallen asleep.
pli-tv-pvr17:244.1: “There are these five advantages, Upāli, for one of raised up mindfulness, who is clearly conscious, when he has fallen asleep.
pli-tv-pvr17:244.3: He sleeps easily, he wakes easily, he does not see an evil dream, devatās guard him, impurity is not emitted.
pli-tv-pvr17:244.4: These are the five advantages … when he has fallen asleep.”
pli-tv-pvr17:245.1: “How many, revered sir, are not to be greeted?”
pli-tv-pvr17:246.1: “These five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:246.3: One who has entered amid the houses is not to be greeted, one who is on a carriage-road is not to be greeted, one who is in the (partial) darkness is not to be greeted, one who is not considering (his duties) is not to be greeted, one who is asleep is not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:246.4: These five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:247.1: “And a further five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:247.3: One who is drinking conjey is not to be greeted, one in a refectory … one who has turned away alone … one who is thinking about something else … one who is naked is not t be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:247.4: These five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:248.1: “And a further five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:248.3: One who is eating solid food is not to be greeted, one who is eating soft food … one who is defecating … one who is urinating … one who is suspended is not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:248.4: These five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:249.1: “And a further five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:249.3: One ordained later is not to be greeted by one ordained earlier, one not ordained is not to be greeted, one belonging to a different communion (even) if he is more senior (yet) is a speaker of non-_dhamma_ is not to be greeted, a woman is not to be greeted a eunuch is not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:249.4: These five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:250.1: “And a further five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:250.3: One under probation is not to be greeted, one who deserves to be sent back to the beginning … one who deserves _mānatta_ … one undergoing _mānatta_ … one who deserves rehabilitation is not to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:250.4: These five, Upāli, are not to be greeted.”
pli-tv-pvr17:251.1: “How many, revered sir, are to be greeted?”
pli-tv-pvr17:252.1: ““These five, Upāli, are to be greeted.
pli-tv-pvr17:252.3: One ordained earlier is to be greeted by one ordained later, one belonging to a different communion if he is more senior and is a speaker of _Dhamma_ is to be greeted, a teacher is to be greeted, a preceptor is to be greeted, a Tathāgata, arahant, perfect Buddha is to be greeted by the world with its devas, with its Māras, with its Brahmās, by creatures with recluses and brahmins, with devas and mankind.
pli-tv-pvr17:252.4: These five, Upāli, are to be greeted.”
pli-tv-pvr17:253.1: “If a more newly ordained monk, revered sir, is honouring the feet of a more senior monk, when he has caused how many states to be set up within himself should he honour the feet?”
pli-tv-pvr17:254.1: “If a more newly ordained monk, Upāli, is honouring the feet of a more senior monk, having caused five states to be set up within himself he should honour the feet.
pli-tv-pvr17:254.3: When a more newly ordained monk, Upāli, is honouring the feet of a more senior monk, having arranged his outer cloak over one shoulder, holding out his joined palms in salutation, stroking his feet on all sides with the palms of his hands, having caused regard and esteem to be set up, he should honour his feet.
pli-tv-pvr17:254.4: When a more newly ordained monk, Upāli, is honouring the feet of a more senior monk, having caused these five states to be set up within himself, he should honour his feet.”
